text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Islamabad has formally lodged a protest with Washington against the "rude and obnoxious remarks" of an American lawyer against the Pakistani nation.
- The government has set up Ehtesab (accountability) committees at district level to weed out corruption.
- President Farooq Leghari condemned the statement of a U.S. lawyer given in a U.S. court during a hearing of the Aimal Kansi case and has demanded an apology from the attorney.
- Fourteen people were killed in sectarian violence in Punjab province, including eight in Shorkot, two in Lahore and four in Jhang.
- A senior police officer and bus driver were killed in eastern Karachi.
- Sindh provincial Health Secretary Shafi Mohammad Qureshi was wounded by unidentified drive-by shooters in Karachi.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will chair a meeting in Islamabad on Tuesday to review budgetary developments.
- Japan Power Generation Ltd is expected to start trial production of electricity from September 1.

- The banking authorities have submitted a voluntary retirement plan for government approval, which ensures that the return on the lump sum amount, if invested, is equivalent to the present take-home salary of the bankers.
- Taking advantage of the excess liquidity in the market, the government has rolled over its rupee debt at two percent lower mark-up than it was paying to the banks a month ago.
- The State (central) Bank has allowed export finance facility for yarns of higher count.
- The Export Committee of Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce and Industry has called for extending most favoured nation treatment to India as mandated by the World Trade Organisation.
- A team of Southern Energy officials is expected to reach Islamabad on August 7 to start negotiations with the government on a $6 billion 5,280-megawatt CEPA power project in Keti Bandar.
